Research Papers on Autonomous Driving and Computer Vision

Svetlana Pavlitska, Nico Lambing, and J Marius Zöllner conducted a survey on adversarial attacks on traffic sign recognition.
The survey was published in the 2023 International Conference on Electrical, Computer, Communications and Mechatronics Engineering.
Xuweiyi Chen and colleagues studied multi-object hallucination in vision-language models.
The research was published as an arXiv preprint in 2024.
Julia Nitsch and researchers investigated out-of-distribution detection for automotive perception.
The study was presented at the 2021 IEEE International Intelligent Transportation Systems Conference.
Mario Bijelic, Tobias Gruber, and Werner Ritter benchmarked image sensors under adverse weather conditions for autonomous driving.
The research was presented at the 2018 IEEE Intelligent Vehicles Symposium.
Ruoxi Zhu and colleagues developed MWFormer, a multi-weather image restoration method using degradation-aware transformers.
The research was published in IEEE Transactions on Image Processing in 2024.
Quanyi Li and team created ScenarioNet, an open-source platform for large-scale traffic scenario simulation and modeling.
The platform was presented in Advances in Neural Information Processing Systems in 2024.
Wenhao Ding and researchers conducted a survey on safety-critical driving scenario generation from a methodological perspective.
The survey was published in IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems in 2023.
Jinlong Li and colleagues developed a multi-condition diffusion framework for low-light enhancement in autonomous driving.
The research was presented at the IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition in 2024.
Shuo Feng and researchers applied dense reinforcement learning for safety validation of autonomous vehicles.
The study was published in Nature in 2023.
Hao Shao and team developed LMDrive, a closed-loop end-to-end driving system using large language models.
The research was presented at the IEEE/CVF Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition in 2024.
Sebastian Krügel and Matthias Uhl conducted an empirical approach to the risk ethics of autonomous vehicles.
The study was published in Scientific Reports in 2024.
Yingzi Ma and colleagues developed Dolphins, a multimodal language model for driving.
The research was presented at the European Conference on Computer Vision in 2025.
Chonghao Sima and team created DriveLM, a driving system with graph visual question answering.
The research was presented at the European Conference on Computer Vision in 2025.
Jyh-Jing Hwang and researchers developed EMMA, an end-to-end multimodal model for autonomous driving.
The research was published as an arXiv preprint in 2024.
Shuo Xing and colleagues created OpenEMMA, an open-source multimodal model for end-to-end autonomous driving.
The research was published as an arXiv preprint in 2024.
Tsun-Hsuan Wang and researchers developed V2VNet, a vehicle-to-vehicle communication system for joint perception and prediction.
The research was presented at the European Conference on Computer Vision in 2020.
